trans-unit.source: Using JConsole to access the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> MBeans

seg-source.mrk: Using JConsole to access the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> MBeans

target.mrk: Using JConsole to access the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> MBeans

trans-unit.source: JConsole is a graphical JMX-compliant tool that is available in recent versions of the Oracle JDKs. JConsole enables you to monitor and manage Java applications and virtual machines on a local or remote machine.

seg-source.mrk: JConsole is a graphical JMX-compliant tool that is available in recent versions of the Oracle JDKs.
JConsole enables you to monitor and manage Java applications and virtual machines on a local or remote machine.

target.mrk: JConsole is a graphical JMX-compliant tool that is available in recent versions of the Oracle JDKs.
JConsole enables you to monitor and manage Java applications and virtual machines on a local or remote machine.

seg-source.mrk: Java Management Extensions (JMX) technology

target.mrk: Java Management Extensions (JMX) technology

seg-source.mrk: JMX

target.mrk: JMX

seg-source.mrk: using JConsole

target.mrk: using JConsole

trans-unit.source: You may use JConsole from JDK 6 or later even if you are running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> using an earlier version of the JDK (or just the JRE). (You could also use JConsole from JDK 5 if you are running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> using JDK 6 or later.) It is recommended that you use the newest version possible. More information about JConsole is available in the OpenJDK project at <xref format="html" href="http://openjdk.java.net/tools/svc/jconsole/index.html" scope="external">http://openjdk.java.net/tools/svc/jconsole/index.html</xref>.

seg-source.mrk: You may use JConsole from JDK 6 or later even if you are running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> using an earlier version of the JDK (or just the JRE).
(You could also use JConsole from JDK 5 if you are running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> using JDK 6 or later.) It is recommended that you use the newest version possible.

More information about JConsole is available in the OpenJDK project at <xref format="html" href="http://openjdk.java.net/tools/svc/jconsole/index.html" scope="external">http://openjdk.java.net/tools/svc/jconsole/index.html</xref>.

target.mrk: You may use JConsole from JDK 6 or later even if you are running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> using an earlier version of the JDK (or just the JRE).
(You could also use JConsole from JDK 5 if you are running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> using JDK 6 or later.) It is recommended that you use the newest version possible.

More information about JConsole is available in the OpenJDK project at <xref format="html" href="http://openjdk.java.net/tools/svc/jconsole/index.html" scope="external">http://openjdk.java.net/tools/svc/jconsole/index.html</xref>.

seg-source.mrk: Starting JConsole and connecting to <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>

target.mrk: Starting JConsole and connecting to <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph>

trans-unit.source: In the Oracle JDK, the JConsole binary is available in <codeph>JDK_HOME/bin</codeph>, where JDK_HOME is the directory in which the JDK is installed. To start JConsole, use the <codeph>jconsole</codeph> command, as in the following example on a UNIX system:

seg-source.mrk: In the Oracle JDK, the JConsole binary is available in <codeph>JDK_HOME/bin</codeph>, where JDK_HOME is the directory in which the JDK is installed.
To start JConsole, use the <codeph>jconsole</codeph> command, as in the following example on a UNIX system:

target.mrk: In the Oracle JDK, the JConsole binary is available in <codeph>JDK_HOME/bin</codeph>, where JDK_HOME is the directory in which the JDK is installed.
To start JConsole, use the <codeph>jconsole</codeph> command, as in the following example on a UNIX system:

seg-source.mrk: /usr/local/java/jdk1.7.0/bin/jconsole

target.mrk: /usr/local/java/jdk1.7.0/bin/jconsole

trans-unit.source: If you did not disable SSL when booting the managed JVM, you probably have to provide a truststore containing the server's SSL certificate to be able to establish JMX connections. If SSL client authentication is enabled, a keystore must be configured as well (see <xref href="radminjmxenablepwdssl.dita#radminjmxenablepwdssl"></xref> for details). The following example shows how to start JConsole with SSL client and server authentication:

seg-source.mrk: If you did not disable SSL when booting the managed JVM, you probably have to provide a truststore containing the server's SSL certificate to be able to establish JMX connections.
If SSL client authentication is enabled, a keystore must be configured as well (see <xref href="radminjmxenablepwdssl.dita#radminjmxenablepwdssl"></xref> for details).
The following example shows how to start JConsole with SSL client and server authentication:

target.mrk: If you did not disable SSL when booting the managed JVM, you probably have to provide a truststore containing the server's SSL certificate to be able to establish JMX connections.
If SSL client authentication is enabled, a keystore must be configured as well (see <xref href="radminjmxenablepwdssl.dita#radminjmxenablepwdssl"></xref> for details).
The following example shows how to start JConsole with SSL client and server authentication:

seg-source.mrk: jconsole -J-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=/home/user/.truststoreForClient -J-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=myTruststorePassword -J-Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/home/user/.keystoreForClient -J-Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=myKeyStorePassword

target.mrk: jconsole -J-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=/home/user/.truststoreForClient -J-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=myTruststorePassword -J-Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore=/home/user/.keystoreForClient -J-Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=myKeyStorePassword

trans-unit.source: A graphical user interface (GUI) appears. For additional startup options, refer to the JConsole documentation. Once the GUI starts, you are presented with a list of the JVMs that are accessible on the local host. Locate the JVM that is running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> and connect to it.

seg-source.mrk: A graphical user interface (GUI) appears.
For additional startup options, refer to the JConsole documentation.
Once the GUI starts, you are presented with a list of the JVMs that are accessible on the local host.
Locate the JVM that is running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> and connect to it.

target.mrk: A graphical user interface (GUI) appears.
For additional startup options, refer to the JConsole documentation.
Once the GUI starts, you are presented with a list of the JVMs that are accessible on the local host.
Locate the JVM that is running <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> and connect to it.

trans-unit.source: To connect to a JVM on a remote host, you will need to supply the host name and port number, or a JMX service URL, instead.

seg-source.mrk: To connect to a JVM on a remote host, you will need to supply the host name and port number, or a JMX service URL, instead.

target.mrk: To connect to a JVM on a remote host, you will need to supply the host name and port number, or a JMX service URL, instead.

trans-unit.source: If you cannot find the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JVM running on the local host, make sure you are running JConsole as the same user as the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JVM, or as a different user with sufficient file system permissions. If you are using Java SE 5, make sure you have enabled JMX. When you use Java SE 6 or later, local JMX access is enabled by default.

seg-source.mrk: If you cannot find the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JVM running on the local host, make sure you are running JConsole as the same user as the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JVM, or as a different user with sufficient file system permissions.
If you are using Java SE 5, make sure you have enabled JMX.
When you use Java SE 6 or later, local JMX access is enabled by default.

target.mrk: If you cannot find the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JVM running on the local host, make sure you are running JConsole as the same user as the <ph conref="../conrefs.dita#prod/productshortname"></ph> JVM, or as a different user with sufficient file system permissions.
If you are using Java SE 5, make sure you have enabled JMX.
When you use Java SE 6 or later, local JMX access is enabled by default.

seg-source.mrk: Accessing MBeans

target.mrk: Accessing MBeans

trans-unit.source: Once you have connected to a JVM via JConsole, the JVM's MBeans should be available on a separate tab in the internal JConsole window. Under the domain <codeph>org.apache.derby</codeph> you should see a list of MBeans. Browse the MBeans and their attributes and operations by navigating the hierarchy presented.

seg-source.mrk: Once you have connected to a JVM via JConsole, the JVM's MBeans should be available on a separate tab in the internal JConsole window.
Under the domain <codeph>org.apache.derby</codeph> you should see a list of MBeans.
Browse the MBeans and their attributes and operations by navigating the hierarchy presented.

target.mrk: Once you have connected to a JVM via JConsole, the JVM's MBeans should be available on a separate tab in the internal JConsole window.
Under the domain <codeph>org.apache.derby</codeph> you should see a list of MBeans.
Browse the MBeans and their attributes and operations by navigating the hierarchy presented.

trans-unit.source: Another useful JConsole feature is that you can view dynamic data represented as JMX attributes in graph form. To view these graphs, double-click an attribute value that is a number.

seg-source.mrk: Another useful JConsole feature is that you can view dynamic data represented as JMX attributes in graph form.
To view these graphs, double-click an attribute value that is a number.

target.mrk: Another useful JConsole feature is that you can view dynamic data represented as JMX attributes in graph form.
To view these graphs, double-click an attribute value that is a number.
